translates as head of the sect; used to show respect towards a leader)', "Guruji (used to address or refer to one' Written by: Alicia Benson, Clinical Assistant Professor and Adjunct Instructor in Nutrition at Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine & Rye Brook Dietetics Practice", 'This article provides some tips on how to make smarter choices when it comes to your grocery shopping and meal planning, as well as ideas for substituting these popular sweet options with lower-calorie alternatives.', 'However, too much sugar in the diet is not healthy', 'They come in two forms: intrinsic sugars that naturally occur in foods such as fruits, vegetables and milk and added sugars that are added during processing or at home when preparing meals', 'This increase could be because sugar-laden foods are cheaper and have become popular for its ability to add flavor (2).', 'Sugar content is listed in grams and as a percentage of total calories per serving', 'Monosaccharides include fructose, glucose and galactose; disaccharides consist of sucrose, lactose and maltose; while polysaccharides are starches.', 'Foods that naturally contain sugars include fruit, milk, honey, maple syrup and table sugar (5).', 'The American Heart Association recommends consuming no more than six teaspoons of added sugar per day for women and nine teaspoons for men (6)', 'Eating more fruits and vegetables can help with this as they are natural sources of these nutrients', "It's also wise to know which foods contain naturally occurring sugars like fruit so you can eat them in moderation without feeling guilty about the calories (5).", 'For example, instead of buying packaged granola bars that have 10g added sugars per bar, opt for homemade oatmeal or make your own trail mix using nuts and dried fruit.', 'Instead of adding artificial sweeteners to enhance the taste, add fresh berries or sliced bananas for a naturally sweet snack option', 'If you do choose to drink a juice with little or no pulp, look for one labeled "100% juice," meaning it was made only from fruits and not water (5).', 'You can also make your own sugar-free lemonade by using freshly squeezed lemons, filtered water and a dash of stevia or monk fruit extract (8).', 'The American Heart Association recommends consuming no more than 5g per serving for women and men (6)', 'For example, you can create a healthy smoothie with unsweetened almond milk, frozen berries, banana slices and spinach or kale', 'Add a dash of natural sweetener like honey instead of maple syrup which has more calories per serving', 'Remember that these are still calorie sources so use them sparingly (8).', 'Try slicing an apple with a tablespoon of peanut butter or dipping carrot sticks in hummus', 'Focus on ['Anthology - A selected and arranged publication of literary works, such as poems or short stories.', 'Compendium - An abridged collection of various texts on a particular subject in one volume.', "Almanac - An annual publication containing information like weather forecasts, farmers' planting dates, tide tables, and other related statistics organized by date.", 'Miscellany - A gathering or mixture of miscellaneous items, typically those that do not fit into any specific category.', 'Encyclopedia - A comprehensive reference work containing articles on a vast range of subjects or on numerous aspects of a particular field.', 'Anthology of Fables - An assembly of various fables from different cultures and periods.', 'Pharmacopoeia - A book that compiles medicinal drugs, their formulations, uses, dosages, etc.', 'Codex - A collection of historical manuscripts in book form.', 'Index - An alphabetical list of names, subjects, etc., with references to the places where they occur, typically found at the end of a book or document.', 'Bibliography - A list of books and other works referred to by an author in writing their work.', 'Miscellaneous Recipe Book - An assortment of recipes from various cuisines and cultures.', 'Time Capsule Collection - A collection of artifacts or documents that represent a particular time period, sealed for future reference.', 'Compiled Listings - Assembled and categorized listings on specific topics or subjects.', 'Reference Guide - An organized collection of information used to find answers to questions in various domains.', 'Field Guide - A book that provides detailed information, often illustrated, about the natural history, identification, behavior, etc., of a particular group of animals or plants.', 'Catch-all Pocket Diary - An unstructured journal where one can jot down miscellaneous thoughts, ideas, events, and experiences.', 'Mixed Media Artwork Collage - A collection of various materials, techniques, and media used in creating an art piece that may not fit into any specific category or style.', 'Historical Archives - Collections of historical documents, records, manuscripts, and other artifacts held by archives or repositories.', 'Miscellaneous Bookshelf - A book collection where books are randomly placed on a shelf without a strict categorization system.', 'Variety Box - A container that holds an assortment of miscellaneous items such as candies, trinkets, or other small objects for display or consumption.']

['Carotene', 'Chlorophyll', 'Lutein', 'Xanthophyll', 'Anthocyanin (when present, it can turn yellow-brown in acidic conditions)', 'Curcumin (from turmeric, a bright yellow to yellow-brown pigment when oxidized)', 'Canthaxanthin (a synthetic colorant used in foods and cosmetics that turns yellow-brown with time)', 'Annatto (a natural dye from the achiote bark, which can give a yellow to orange hue depending on processing)', 'Geosmin (an earthy flavor and odor compound produced by soil fungi; not directly a pigment but can have yellow-brown color implications in certain contexts)', 'Flavonoids (a class of plant secondary metabolites that include various colors, including some yellow to brownish tones when present in high concentrations or specific forms like aurantinidin and vitexin)', 'Quercetin (flavonol found in many fruits, vegetables, leaves, and grains; can have a yellow-brown color depending on its concentration and state)', 'Luteolin (a flavone with yellow to brownish hues when present at certain levels)', 'Saffron (contains carotenoids like crocin which impart a yellow to orange color, but can appear more golden-brown in culinary uses due to processing and blending)', 'Catechol (an organic compound with an o-diphenol structure that has a brownish tone when oxidized)', 'Limonene (while primarily known as a yellow citrus oil, it can exhibit some brown hues in impure samples or through degradation)', 'Curcumin (as mentioned earlier, curcumin from turmerinas an orange-yellow to yellow-brown pigment when aged)', 'Zeaxanthin (a carotenoid found in nature as a blue-green plant pigment but can present shades of yellow-brown under certain conditions)', "Lycopene (the red pigment from tomatoes, papayas, and other fruits; it doesn't typically display yellow-brown coloring directly but may be influenced by food processing or interaction with other compounds)", 'Apocarotenoids (a class of carotenoid breakdown products that include pigments like apocarotene which can appear yellow to brownish)', 'Phenolic acids (an umbrella term for a group of plant secondary metabolites, some of which have color implications including variations in the yellow-brown range such as ferulic and p-coumaric acid derivatives when oxidized or complexed with other compounds).']

CLUE: Essential part of accusation about grave man
OUTPUT: ['Allegation - A claim or assertion made without proof, typically one made against someone in relation to a crime.', 'Grievance - A real or imagined cause for complaint, especially unfair treatment.', 'Accusation - An expression of blame for an offense or wrongdoing.', 'Indictment - The formal charge that a person has committed a serious crime.', 'Condemnation - Expressing strong disapproval of someone or something, often in relation to their actions.', 'Denunciation - A forcefully disapproving statement about someone or something; an official condemnation.', 'Incrimination - The act of implicating someone as involved in a crime.', 'Prosecution - The action or process of bringing a criminal case against someone for trial.', "Vindication - Act of clearing someone from blame or suspicion; justifying one's actions or innocence.", 'Exoneration - Decision by an official body such as a court that a person was not guilty of the crime they were accused of committing.', 'Conviction - A judgment that someone is guilty of a criminal offense, typically after a trial and verdict.', 'Admission - Confession or acknowledgment by an individual admitting guilt for wrongdoing.', 'Accusation - The expression of blame towards an individual or entity.', 'Allegation - A claim that someone has done something illegal or wrong, especially one made without proof.', 'Complaint - A statement expressing dissatisfaction or faults; a formal charge or accusation.', 'Misdemeanor - A minor crime usually punishable by fine and/or short-term imprisonment.', 'Felony - A serious crime, typically one involving violence, that is punishable by imprisonment for more than one year or death.', 'Perjury - The act of lying or making false statements under oath in a court of law.', 'Fraud - Deception intended to result in financial or personal gain.', 'Misconduct - Improper behavior, especially by an official or public person; unacceptable conduct.']
